semantic_identifier: Impact--Add counterfactual “what would improve fit” suggestions to Fit Score explainability.docx

hierarchy.file_name: Impact--Add counterfactual “what would improve fit” suggestions to Fit Score explainability.docx

sections.text:
This feature adds counterfactual “what would improve fit” guidance to Fit Score explainability by returning the minimal set of changes to key signals that would materially increase an account/segment’s Fit Score. Instead of only describing why a score is high or low, the explainability service will also output a small, deterministic list of actionable levers (e.g., firmographics thresholds, product usage milestones, integrations adopted, support volume patterns) and the expected score lift from each.

The primary impact is making Fit Score more operational for GTM and product teams: reps and CSMs can quickly understand which controllable actions (like enabling a specific integration or hitting a usage benchmark) are most likely to move an account into a higher-fit bracket, while analysts can use consistent, bounded outputs for reporting and experimentation. For product, it creates a direct bridge between scoring inputs and activation/enablement programs by identifying the highest-impact “next best steps” implied by the model’s signals.

To keep outcomes trustworthy and usable, the response schema will be deterministic and capped (top N suggestions) with explicit field/value changes and an expected delta, ensuring stable results across runs and easy UI/consumer integration. Safety constraints prevent leakage of PII and avoid recommendations that are impossible or nonsensical (e.g., suggesting changes to immutable attributes), which protects customer trust and reduces the risk of guidance being misinterpreted as prescriptive or invasive.

Engineering/test impact includes extending the explainability service logic and adding coverage for edge cases: low-signal accounts where few levers exist, conflicting signals where improving one dimension may worsen another, and strict enforcement of output size caps. These tests and constraints reduce regressions and ensure the feature degrades gracefully, producing either safe, limited guidance or a clear “insufficient signals” style response when appropriate.
